text: one of my all-time favorite desserts is
creme caramel what about you is it your
all-time favorite dessert - well if it
is you're going to be super excited
today because today I'm making creme
caramel a couple of little things that
you need to know about it but it's
really not that hard I think the hardest
thing of all is making the caramel which
is the first step and it's not hard you
just have to be patient in this pot I
have four tablespoons of water I'm
adding one cup of granulated sugar you
can make caramel without adding water
what the water does is help dissolve
everything to start off with that way
there are no crystals in the sugar and
then you have less of a chance of your
sugar crystallizing which is one of the
things that you have to look out for
when you're making caramel so what you
want to do is when you first add your
sugar stir it so that the sugar
dissolves in the water have it on a
medium high heat and then once it's all
dissolved don't stir again just let it
sit there cooking over a medium-high
heat swirling occasionally until it
turns a dark amber you can swirl it but
don't put the spoon back in there the
spoon might have little crystals of
sugar on there and those crystals of
sugar actually can make your sugar
crystallize instead of caramelize it's
crazy
keep an eye on it it's starting to brown
it's getting very very close it's a
light amber right now and this is when
you have to really really watch it
because it goes very quickly at this
point in fact once it starts looking
pretty dark amber turn it off and then
the residual cooking of the hot sugar
will bring it to the color that you want
which is a dark amber to by the caramel
between eight four ounce ramekins do it
quickly you can always go back but you
want to make sure each one gets a little
bit of caramel I have them in a large
roasting dish because I'm going to cook
these in a boiling water bath so you
need them to be in a roasting pan
perfect
excellent the hard part is over over
here I'm going to separate some eggs
whisk two large eggs and three large egg
yolks into a half a cup of sugar which I
have in this bowl and then three large
egg yolks with two teaspoons pure
vanilla extract and 1/8 of a teaspoon of
salt whisk together when everything is
nicely combined then you're going to
ladle in three cups of warm milk start
with one ladle at a time just to
gradually warm up your mixture then you
want to strain it through a sieve to
remove any little if there's any little
bits of cooked egg you want to make sure
you get rid of them so use a fine sieve
then the egg custard mixture gets poured
on top of the caramel into the ramekins
these large measuring cups are perfect
for this because obviously they have a
spout and they're easy to strain into so
if you don't have one go out and get one
I love mine I have my oven preheating to
325 degrees and I have some water in a
kettle coming to a boil because you need
to cook this in a boiling water back
what that means is cook it surrounded by
hot water it's a very gentle cooking
method there's a roasting pan with the
custards in it on a rack in your oven
and then add hot water to come about
halfway up the sides of the ramekins be
careful not to get any of the water into
the custard cups and then close your
oven the custards need to cook until
they're just set in the center that
should take about thirty five minutes
when they're done just remove them using
tongs out of the water and let them cool
a little bit and then refrigerate them
for four hours they're chilled they're
set they're ready to turn out all you
need to do take a paring knife run it
around the edges this is not an exact
science
then take your custard cup and a plate
turn the plate up over on top of your
cup and then turn the cop upside down
and in theory when I lift this off the
custard will come out
with the caramel all talk over the top I
said it was in theory right Oh tada I
told you it would happen caramel on top
custard on the bottom I'm eating it
right now I am not waiting for you guys
as I mentioned earlier this one of my
